thread.title: SEC game changers: Tennessee, Missouri need passing games to shine
thread.title_full: SEC game changers: Tennessee, Missouri need passing games to shine

author: Zach Winslett
title: SEC game changers: Tennessee, Missouri need passing games to shine
text:
SEC game changers: Tennessee, Missouri need passing games to shi - CBS46 News Member Center: SEC game changers: Tennessee, Missouri need passing games to shine Posted: zwinslett@raycommedia.com Missouri quarterback Drew Lock throws a pass during the third quarter of an NCAA college football game against South Carolina Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015, in Columbia, Mo. (AP Photo/L.G. Patterson) Tennessee wide receiver Josh Smith (25) is hit as he makes a catch by Arkansas linebacker Dre Greenlaw (23) and defensive back Jared Collins (29). (AP Photo/Wade Payne) 
(RNN) - In its three losses this season, Tennessee has lost by a combined 12 points. 
That’s a misleading stat, though. The Volunteers’ games have been even closer than that. 
This team, which was lauded in the offseason as a much-improved-upon franchise, is 12 points away from being undefeated and leading the SEC East, as many predicted they would. 
As it is now, however, Tennessee sits at 2-3 and winless in conference play. That’s why this weekend’s game is so crucial. 
When the reeling Volunteers host Georgia on Saturday, it’s likely their last chance to carve out a piece of the SEC East race - they’re going to need a lot of help even if they win, but it’s about proving a point, too. 
Luckily, Tennessee isn’t the only team reeling. Georgia was blew out by Alabama last week, which gave Florida sole control of the SEC East. 
Speaking of the Gators, there is no team with more hype surrounding them than Florida. It’s still a little too soon for that, though. 
Their opponent this week is plagued by an injury at the signal caller position and flying under the radar, but the Missouri Tigers still deserve respect. 
They are, after all, the reigning two-time SEC East champ. If Florida wants the throne, it will have to depose the incumbent king. 
Georgia vs Tennessee 
Player to look out for: Someone in Tennessee’s passing game 
This may look like a cop-out at first, but, at this point, the Volunteers are begging for anyone to show up. 
Quarterback Joshua Dobbs received a lot of attention in the offseason, and he was expected to be a big part of Tennessee’s success. Any preseason ideas haven't come to fruition yet. 
While Dobbs has managed to remain an electrifying player, he hasn’t been able to generate consistent offense through the air. Even when Dobbs was the leading passer, rusher and receiver during the Vols’ game against Florida, he still only managed to pass for 83 yards. Oh, and his team lost a heartbreaker. 
The junior quarterback isn’t necessarily losing games for the Tennessee, but the team needs more from its passing game. The Volunteers have given up big leads in each of their losses, which could have been remedied with a little more octane on offense. 
The receivers are to blame as well. Tennessee doesn’t have a receiver with more than 157 yards receiving. 
Something has to change for Tennessee, and this is the perfect week to do it. A win over Georgia is exactly what the team needs to restore much-needed confidence, and the schedule isn’t going to get any easier with Alabama looming on the horizon. 
Florida vs Missouri 
Player to look out for: Missouri QB Drew Lock 
Missouri is the two-time champion of the SEC East. That’s quite the feat for a team that’s only been a member of the conference since 2012. 
The Tigers are far from a favorite to represent the conference in Atlanta again this year, but they cannot be ruled out, as proven by the last two years. 
This week will truly test the grit of Tigers. When they square off against the new hottest team in the SEC, Florida, they’ll be going at it without veteran quarterback Maty Mauk. 
Mauk, who was recently suspended, led Missouri in both of its appearances in the title game. In his shoes now is Drew Lock, a true freshman. 
Lock performed admirably last week against South Carolina. He tossed two touchdowns and went 21-28 for 136 yards. Most importantly, he protected the ball. 
This week, however, he’s going up against one of the best defenses in the SEC. 
There isn’t much material to analyze Lock on. So the breakdown is simple - he must protect the ball like he did against a lesser team last week if he wants to find a win.
